raw_comment:
1. I notice that being in the 80th percentile of income without legacy reduces the chances of being
accepted. In contrast, students in the 99th percentile without legacy are still twice as likely to get accepted
into the school. The only time the grey dips below the average is between the 75th and 90th percentile of
earnings.
2. I wonder why students without legacy who live in families with very high incomes have greater
chances of getting into colleges, could it be other factors such as reputation?
3. Many people in my community who apply to college must compete with other students who get a
massive boost simply by being the child of a former student. This is a major struggle for people working
very hard trying to achieve their dreams only to lose to the college system.
4. "Legacy and Luxury: The Admissions Advantage Unveiled in Elite Colleges"

A student can have no legacy status.
If a student is in the 80th percentile of income and has no legacy status then the acceptance chance of the student is reduced.
A student can be in the 99th percentile of income.
If a student is in the 99th percentile of income and has no legacy status then the student is still twice as likely to be accepted as an average student.
The grey line represents a value.
The grey line dips below the average only between the 75th percentile and the 90th percentile of earnings.
Some students have no legacy status.
Some students live in families with very high incomes.
These students have greater chances of getting into colleges.
